title: Moles to Mass
description: Calculate mass from moles and molar mass

examples.problem: Calculate the mass of 0.500 mol of NaCl (molar mass = 58.4 g/mol).

study_tips.concept: This calculation converts moles (from stoichiometric calculations) back to mass (what you can actually weigh out in the laboratory).
key_points: Multiply moles by molar mass to get mass
Essential for determining theoretical and actual yields
Used when preparing specific amounts of substances
vce_connections: Unit 1 AoS 2: Stoichiometric calculations and limiting reagents
Unit 3 AoS 1: Quantitative analysis and solution preparation
Unit 4 AoS 1: Yield calculations in industrial processes
common_errors: Dividing instead of multiplying (confusing with mass to moles)
Using atomic mass instead of molar mass for compounds
Forgetting significant figures based on given data
extensions: How does this relate to percent yield calculations?
What if you needed to account for hydrated salts?
How would you scale this up for industrial production?

interactive_questions.question: How many grams are in 0.750 mol of sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄)? Molar mass = 98.08 g/mol
interactive_questions.follow_up: 73.6 g of H₂SO₄. This is how you'd prepare a specific amount for a reaction or solution.

interactive_questions.question: Calculate the mass of 2.50 mol of glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆). Molar mass = 180.16 g/mol
interactive_questions.follow_up: 450 g of glucose! This demonstrates why we use moles - it's easier to work with 2.5 mol than 450 g in calculations.
